description: [Status: stable] [Name: unnecessary-generator-list] [Message: Unnecessary generator (rewrite using list())] What it does Checks for unnecessary generators that can be rewritten as list comprehensions (or with list() directly). Why is this bad? It is unnecessary to use list() around a generator expression, since there are equivalent comprehensions for these types. Using a comprehension is clearer and more idiomatic. Further, if the comprehension can be removed entirely, as in the case of list(x for x in foo), it's better to use list(foo) directly, since it's even more direct. Example list(f(x) for x in foo) list(x for x in foo) list((x for x in foo)) Use instead: [f(x) for x in foo] list(foo) list(foo) Fix safety This rule's fix is marked as unsafe, as it may occasionally drop comments when rewriting the call. In most cases, though, comments will be preserved.
